Plant tolerance is considered to be costly because tissue is lost through herbivory. Furthermore, the reserves allocated to tolerance cannot be used for other functions such as survival, growth, or reproduction
12 . Therefore, plant genotypes that have high levels of tolerance are expected to show poorer growth than genotypes with lower tolerance. Although tolerance plays a significant role in the way plants cope with herbivore attack
10 , its evolutionary consequences have rarely been studied within the framework of the EICA and SDH and evidence collected so far is controversial
15â€“ 19 . Invasive species that have been freed from their specialist herbivores for many generations are an ideal system to study the selective pressures on tolerance. In this study, we tested the hypothesis that invasive plants have evolved towards a decreased investment in tolerance and an increased investment in growth.
